MS FLIERS
VOL. XXV. No. 1
Y. M. C. A. HOLDS ANNUAL
RECEPTION
Dr. French Addresses Students in Behalf of Faculty—Student Organizations Poorly Represented.
The Y. M. C. A. reception to the
Freshmen, held Friday evening in
the Civil Engineering Hall, attracted an almost 100 per cent.
attendance of Freshmen • but the
affair lacked the cordiality it
would have possessed had more
upper classmen been present. The
Y. M. C. A., Harold Reed and Mr.
E. Pearce Hayes deserve a great
measure of credit for the success
the reception, nevertheless, proved
to be.
Harold Reed opened the evening
by introducing Dr. French, who
made the-welcoming speech of the
faculty to the Freshmen. Dr.
French's remarks took the form of
a few words • of advice which he
said he had to offer, and although
given to Freshmen, the advice is
good for every Hopkins man.
Following Dr. French's address
the assembly heard a few words
from Coach Van Orman, Mr. Kistler and Assistant Coach Wilcox.
The officers of the various activities then presented their organizations' aims to the Freshmen.
The number of these executives
absent was deplorable and against
every Hopkins tradition. During
these announcements the whole
Sophomore class filed out in anticipation of the traditional rush
of
which was to follow the serving
•
refreshments.
The rush proved to be a mildly
interesting event, in which the
honors must go to the Sophomores, although the Freshmen
soon became kings of the walk
when they had found a leader to
take the place of their president,
Hubert Barton, who was pre•vented from participating by the
necessity of keeping in trim for
the morrow's football game. The
Sophomores, however, had by this
time kidnapped a score or more of
Freshmen and transported them
to unknown rural parts. The recent split, reported at their last
class meeting, does not seem to
have affected their well-known
ability to organize for a fight
ahead of time.
The Impossible and the Difficult.

The only difference is that it
takes longer to do the impossible.
The impossible was accomplished
lasit week when the Y. M. C. A.
.was able to secure sufficient rooming and boarding places for all the
students. Homes were found for
250 men and women. It is a safe
prediction to make that unless the
dormitories are ready for use next
year, many students will be compelled to live at a distance from
the University.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 5, 1920

FOOTBALL TEAM OPENS SEASON WITH VICTORY
Downs Mt. St. Mary's by 33 to 14 Score. Fumbles Costly for
Black and Blue.
The Johns Hopkins football team ushered in its 1920 season by
coming from behind and defeating the eleven of Mt. St. Mary's College
by the score of 33 to 14. After the first quarter no one could doubt
that Hopkins was the superior, both on the offensive and the defensive,
for Mt. St. Mary's was unable to stop their powerful smashes through
the line, while her own attack, except at rare intervals, was smothered
by the Black and Blue. The Mountaineers were greatly aided during
the first quarter by several costly fumbles committed by Hopkins, but
their early advantage, and with it the gloom of the Homewood stands,
soon passed when Van Orman's squad found itself and swung into its
real stride.
The contest was characterized by both teams' use of straight football, the great majority of the plays being made through the center of
the line or off-tackle. Hopkins did not attempt a single forward pass,
while Mt. St. Mary's two attempts were failures; one was grounded
and the other.intercepted.. Neither side gained much by the numerous
punts made during the first half, though St. Mary's seemed to get
down under the ball faster. The game was a straight contest in line
•
plunging, and the more powerful and better trained team won.
Elmer Jones stood head and shoulders above any man on the field,
although it would be hard to pick a really weak spot in the Hopkins
machine. He plowed through the line with all his old power, and on
the defensive backed up the line with a rush that instilled respect into
the biggest upstater on the field. Right behind him were Calkins and
Skinner with their dashing smashes, and Landy and McKay, who
always opened up a big hole when it was most needed. For Mt. St.
Mary's, Captain Chapman was the whole show. He scored all of his
team's points, and was, in fact, the only man who could make any
impression at all on the Hopkins defense. He seemed to be right in
the thick of every play, and supplied the only punch that the Mountaineers possessed.

AMBITIOUS PROGRAM
PLANNED
Production Equal to the "Admiral
Crichton," and Several Smaller
Plays Will Probably Be Presented by Dramatic Club.

Production by the Dramatic
Club of a play equal in size to the
"Admirable Crichton" which the
club produced last year is on the
schedule of the dramatic organization for the coining year, according_ to an announcement made last
week by officials of the club. In
addition, several smaller plays,
such as were presented in the
"Barn" last year, will be offered if
there is sufficient demand for
them. The principal play to be
produced has not yet been decided
upon, but it is regarded as certain
that a production of lavish size
and demanding considerable histronic talent will be offered.
Opportunities for members of
the lower classes to-get a place in
the productions of the club are excellent. The club finds itself in
the singular position of having but
eight members of the cast and
business staff remaining, all the
others having graduated last
spring. Consequently, there will
be an excellent opportunity for
ambitious men who wish to show
their school spirit to become members of the club and take part in
the productions. Notice for tryouts in the cast will be made as
soon as the play is definitely decided upon.
It is hoped that Miss Clementine Walter, under whose able direction the plays during the last
three years have been produced,
can be prevailed upon to coach for
one more year. Her assistance in
past-years has been immensely valuable to the Dramatic Club, and
the club would feel completely lost
without her help. Bartus Trew,
president of the club, has not returned from his trip west, and in
the meantime Holmes Boyd is in
complete charge.
The only thing that will limit
the activities of the club will be
the state of finances, according to
Holmes Boyd, the business manager. At present the financial affairs of the club are at a rather
low ebb and will not permit a very
pretentious schedule, but it is certain that after a thorough reorganization the club will be able to
furnish at least as much to the
dramatic activities of the University as last year.

MERICA is fast becoming a pipe smoking country. Every
year more and more men are realizing the comfort, the satisfaction, and the economy of the pipe. And by natural selection,
more and more men are smoking W D C Pipes. This is not
chance. It is because W D C Pipes offer the utmost in pipe value.
Honest French briar, seasoned by our own special process make
W D C Pipes break in sweet and mellow. Coupled with that is a
self-governed body of pipe makers whose sole object is to fashion
pipes which are without peers in all the world. And it has been
accomplished. Ask any good dealer.

At the first Assembly of the
student body last Thursday, Dean
Latane explained the purpose of
these scheduled weekly gatherings.
The first few meetings will be confined to various announcements,
but later the hour will be devoted
to addresses by prominent outside
men. Dr. Latane requested the
students' co-operation in, making
this a feature of college life at
Hopkins.
• He then explained that the student body here had been placed
on a. basis of self-government
through the student council and
the acceptance of the honor system. The honor system, he asserted, must be rigidly enforced,
'because the University cannot afford to put its stamp on it man
when he goes out from its halls
unless he has a high sense of
honor.
Coach Van Orman made -a brief
address, in which he asserted that
with the loyal support of the student body, in spite of the heavy
schedule, the team may be expected to win a majority of its
games.
Mr. Kistler requested all students to assist him in collecting a
mailing list and selling season
tickets. Ninety-five jobs have
been created in connection with
the football season, which he announced would be given to deserving men.

Wm. DEMUTH at CO., NEW YORK

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 5, 1920

With the inauguration of the
year 1920-1921, the News-Letter
looks forward with a great deal
of confidence and hope to the making of a banner year at Johns
Hopkins, not only in scholastic attainments, but in athletic prowess
and all other branches of endeavor.
Our facilities for learning are
improving as each year goes by.
We are becoming acclimated to
our new surroundings at Homewood; more and better equipment
is being placed at the disposal of
the students, and the dormitories,
which, we hope, will put the last
touch on the "get-together" spirit,
will soon be built. With their
completion the "big family" at
Homewood wil feel itself to be
truly a crowd of brothers, pulling
ever more and more for each tither
and for the Alma Mater, and the
college spirit manifested at other
colleges will, we have every con- fidence in assuming, find adequate
soil for growth at Homewood.
But why wait for the dormitories? Let us prove that we can
have that spirit without them.
Our athletic outlook far surpasses that of any year previous,
both in the schedules and quality
of play which will be exhibited.
We face this year the most difficult schedules yet compiled in every branch of sport; our coaching
system outshines that of previous
years, and the material with which
the coaches have to work is better than in years past.

The only way for Johns Hopkins to uphold her end of the arduous schedules assumed this year is
for every man in the University to
put forth his best. Go out for the
teams. If you are not physically
qualified to • make a team, attend
the games, cheer your comrades to
success by your presence and your
voice. Show Baltimoreans that
you are back of your teams heart
and soul, ready to support them
in defeat as well as in victory.
Nothing does a team, fighting an
uphill battle, more good than to
know that every colleze-mate is in
the stands, watching its every play
and pulling for it to deliver the
goods.
Welcome to the University,
Freshmen! We are truly glad to
accept you into our midst.
As you have all undoubtedly observed, there are a few light regulations which you are called upon
to obey. Do not get the idea that
this is hazing; that these small
hardships are placed on your
shoulders by the Sophomores to
afford them amusement at your
expense.
These regulations are put in
force by the Student Council for
your own welfare—to teach you
your position in the University, to
make true and loyal Hopkins men
out of you. The Sophomores are
automatically appointed to carry
out these regulations, but bear in
mind that the entire student body,
and likewise the faculty, is behind
them, ready, if necessary, to aid
the Class of '23 in executing them
to the letter.
Let us hope that you will obey
these regulations with a good
grace, accepting them at their face
value, and bearing no malice
against their enforcers.
If you do this, rest assured that
you will be accepted sooner—and
with greater pleasure—as faithful
college-mates.
As you may have read elsewhere in this issue, the Johns Hopkins R. 0. T. C. has sent out a plea
for recruits. The Johns Hopkins
Unit has ever stood among the
leaders in this branch of the service, in spite of the many hardships
which it has been called upon to
face, and the University is justly
proud of its achievement's.
That the Unit may continue to
hold its place among the leaders,
it requires the support of the
student-body. It needs men -men ready to work with its interests at heart who are not afraid of
a little trouble and exertion.
Show Major Gary, whose face
has been seen in our midst but a
short while, that you are with him
in his plans to put Hopkins at the
head of the R. 0. T. C. Units
throughout the country show him
that we have red-blooded Americans at college who are willing
to support a good thing, and enroll
in the Johns Hopkins Unit. It
will be a step which you will have
no cause to reget later, and will
afford you splendid training for
after-life, as well as giving' you
several credits toward graduation.

The NEWS-LETTER is facing this
year an increase in its printing
cost of over thirty per cent. By
increasing its advertising rates
and raising its subscription it has
been able to meet a large proportion of this increase, but in order
to have a safe margin it needs a
one hundred per cent. student subscription list. Pay your NEWSLETTER bill now at the postoffice
or at the NEWS-LETTER office, and
thus show that the NEWS-LETTER
has your support.
Within the next few days the
Junior and Senior classes will
elect their officers for the coming
year. The real value of these class
offices depends upon the ability
and character of the men Who fill
them. It is therefore of the utmost importance that these Masses
select suitable men for these positions. They should select men
who during their stay at college
have proved themselves popular,
efficient, capable and, above all,
imbued with college spirit and a
willingness to sacrifice themselves
personally for the good of the University. The prestige of these
classes and the good of the University will be seriously affected if
the men are chosen solely on the
grounds of athletic prominence or
false popularity.
WHEN THE CLASS IS OVER, and
you have nothing else to do,
come down to the "Barn" and play
the piano, read the magazines and
daily newspapers, or just loaf.
This room is furnished by the Y.
M. C. A., and is for your use at
any and all times.

Lost-and-Found Bureau.

A long-felt need has been met in
the establishment of the University Lost and Found Bureau. The
conduct of the bureau will be in
the hands of the University Y. M.
C. A., with John P. Stump,'23,'in
charge.
Articles lost or found are to be
reported to the bureau in the Y. M.
C. A. office, where a receipt will be
(riven to the finder. Articles unclaimed after a period of two
weeks will be returned to the
finder. The bureau will post a
daily report on the bulletin-board
near the postoffice.

University Bible Classes.

The Bible classes this year will

R.0. T. C. CALLS FOR RECRUITS.

The Editor of the NEWS-LETTER
has kindly invited me to write an
article explaining the plans for
the coming, year in the Military
Department. In availing myself
of this offer I desire, first, to pay
tribute to my predecessors, Majors
Guild and Ellis, for their services
in this department to the institution. It will be a source of no little satisfaction to the University
to learn that not only their general policy, but many of the details of their administration, have
been accepted by the War Department as a model, and instructions
have just been issued inaugurating the Johns Hopkins system of
military training in all the colleges and universities of the entire
country having infantry training.
The new instructions vitally
change all previous R. 0. T. C.
methods at all institutions except
this one. In this work I was taken
into the confidence of the War Department and have assisted somewhat in the preparation of the
new scheme of instruction for the
country.
To have a Military Department
in the distinguished class three
years after the department was
started is, I believe, a unique record. Major Guild designed the
structure and built the foundation. Major Ellis finished the
work. It will be my policy to continue their policy.
The following interesting and
far-reaching method of appointments in the unit goes into effect
at once: Every second-year man
will be a non-commissioned officer. Those who have been most
proficient and valuable will be sergeant-major or first sergeants
others on down to the grade of
lance corporals. Every man in the
third-year course will be a first
lieutenant, a second lieutenant or
an additional second lieutenant.
Every fourth-year student will be
a field officer, a captain or an additional captain.
The purpose of the above arrangement is to put upper classmen in the position of leaders.
They are to be given opportunities
to command, thus developing by
actual practice the qualities of
Leadership not only indispensible
in military activities, but also valuable in most of civic pursuits.
The Military Department is not
wholly attempting to make soldiers out of the men taking its
training. Not one man in a hundred in this University will go in
the army. With all other Amen--

cans I hope and pray that we may
never again be called upon to go
to war. But such an ideal cannot
be expected. Assuredly in hoping
with all our hearts for peace, no
real American would have us fail
to be reasonably prepared for
whatever eventualities may arise.
The men who served in the
World war have done their full
and honorable duty. They should
now step off the stage. The new
generation should take their
places and assume their work.
The R. 0. T. C. is a means for the.
young men to do so.
Johns Hopkins has taken the
initiative in the new War Department's system of training. Its
schedule for the year is being blueprinted and sent to every college
in the country that has infantry
training. Also, the Johns Hopkins lesson sheets for the year are
being sent all over the country.
That means that we must not
only remain on the distinguished
list, but that we are making a positive and energetic drive ,to stand
No. 1 and to be so recognized
throughout the country.
I can assure every man that
the Johns Hopkins unit has the
respect and confidence of the War
Oepartment. I have been advised
that several important heads of
departments and committees are
coming over this next year to inspect the unit and to see at first
hand the course of instruction
that is having far-reaching results
throughout the country. To be
worthy of our task this new department in the University needs
the moral support and active assistance of every man in it. The
question is this: Shall we continue to have it grow and develop,
or shall we rest on laurels previously won? To come up to the
highest expectations of the Universi[ty authorities and the War
Department we need two things—
first, good men second, hard
work.
To be perfectly frank, we want
no slackers. Only men who want
to put their shoulders to the wheel
and 'push hard are desired. The
Government is offering many attractive features to R. 0. T. C.
men.. The University grants them
liberal credits for graduation. I
have an adequate staff of most
able: assistants. We are going to
give the R. 0, T. C. men our levelbest work. We expect the R. 0.
T. C. men in the unit to give us
50-50.
The first year is devoted to foot
work. The following three years

The Hopkins football team this
year has the honor and responsibility of being the first team to
represent Hopkins on the field under the new athletic regime. It
is the first team to be backed adequately in a financial way, and is
unusually fortunate in being sufficiently equipped, fed at a training table and in having the services of so excellent a coach as Dr.
Van Orman. But these advantages, so customary for other big
colleges and so unique at Hopkins, are not nearly so unprecedented as the training trip to
Camp Red Cloud which the team
took during two weeks in September.
The main body of the squad arrived in camp Monday morning,
September 6, and from that moment till they toiled to break
camp on Saturday, the 18th, the
aspiring gridders lived a hard,
regular life, 15 miles from the
nearest jazz emporium, and that
same 15 miles from -"sugar and
spice and everything nice." But
the hardening procesii was not
left entirely to the routinte of
camp life; the main object of all
this hardening was not allowed to
leave the men's minds for a moment, and Coach Van Orman put
them through two driving football
practices daily. Any spare time
was put in with the axe at the
woodpile or in the woods, swimming in Silver Lake or canoeing
thereon, or in that grand old indoor sport of listening to chalk
talks.
All the time at camp was not
taken up with work, however, and
all the camp life was not hardship, for Camp Red Cloud is a
really ideal camp. Situated on
the shore of Silver Lake, fairly in
the midst of the beautiful trees
that fringe its icy waters, the
camp offered opportunities for
rare fishing and swimming. Since
the lake is over 1800 feet above
sea level, it is entirely spring-fed,
and its waters are so clear that
one can see bottom when the waters are 15 feet deep.
The team this year is a good
one, but, facing such an unusually
heavy schedule, it could scarcely
have attempted to start the season without these preparations.
The schedule, which follows, contains four big games and no easy
ones:
October 2 — Mount St. Mary's,
at Homewood.
. October 9—Syracuse, at Syracuse.
October 16—University of Virginia, at Homewood.
October 23 — Swarthmore, at
Homewood.
October 30 — Georgetown, at
Homewood.
November 6 — Haverford, at
Haverford.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 5, 1920
DEPARTMENT OF PSYCHOLOGY
PRESENTS NEW COURSE.
The department of psychology
has announced for the present
year the inauguration of a new
course in the psychology of music,
to be conducted by Mr. Otto Ortmann, who has recently been appointed an instructor in the University. Mr. Ortman has been for
the past eight years a teacher of
piano at the Peabody Conservatory of Music, and for some time
instructor in music at the Park
School, and has, moreover, done
quite an amount of composing.
The course which he is to give
represents one of the most modern
and recent branches of experimental psychology, and is one of
the first to be attempted in this
particular department of the science. Its fundamental problem
will be the investigation of the
underlying causes of human reactions to certain types of• sounds
and of compositions, the reasons
for the difference in the impressions conveyed, and the effect of
various outside factors on our general'response.
Such a study will lead to a comparison of the different systems of
music, many of which have been
developed by a particular nation.
Experiment will also be made
with tone systems other than the
one now in universal use throughout Europe and America, which
divides the scale into twelve halftones. The chief purpose of the
instruction will thus be to show
the intimate relation which exists
between science and music, and
the dependence of the latter on the
former.
The new course will also deal
with the practical phase of the
study of music, taking up the various forms of music, types of composition, the historical development of harmony,and the study of
rhythm.
Although the course is intended
primarily for graduate students,
those who can show sufficient mu
sical training will be admitted, in
spite of their lack of bachelor's degree. Moreover, a large amount of
technical training is not required,
for one need not be able to play a
particular instrument to gain ad
mission.
November 13—St. John's College, at Homewood.
November 20 — Western Maryland College, at Homewood.
November 25 — University of
Maryland (Maryland State), at
Homewood.

MAJOR CAREY TO HEAD
UNIT
Will Take Place of Captain Ellis who
Retired. Unit to March in
Inaugural Parade.

The organization of the Johns
Hopkins unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps will take
place Tuesday, October 5, at 4
P. M. The battalion this year is
under the command of Maj. Enoch
B. Garey, who succeeds Captain
Ellis as Professor of Military Science and Tactics. The adjutant of
the military department is Capt.
T. L. McMurray, Infantry, and
Major Garey is also assisted by
Regt. Sergt.-Major E. Grummon.
•Members of the unit will wear
on their uniforms this year a gold
star to signify that their outfit is
on the "Distinguished List" of 15
colleges. Uniforms will be issued
during this week.
Enrollment in the unit this fall
promises to be a record one, and it
was stimulated last week by the
appearance of a notice to this
effect:
"Arrangements are now being
made for this unit to march in the
inaugural parade in Washington
on March 4,. 1921, and unless unforeseen circumstances arise it
may be assumed that the battalion
will participate in the parade.
"(Signed) E. B. GAREY,
"Major, Infantry."
Maj. Enoch B. Garey, our new
Professor of Military Science and
Tactics, is a native of Denton,Md.,
and is the son of the late Col. R. J.
W. Garey and Mrs. Garey. He is
a graduate of St. John's and West
Point. As a lieutenant-colonel
in the American Expeditionary
Forces, Major Garey saw active
service in France during the late
summer of 1918. On September
17 of that year Major Garey, in
command of the Eighteenth Machine Gun Battalion of the Sixth
Division, led a daring attack
against the Germans in the Vosges
Mountains for which he was
awarded the Croix de Guerre.
After the armistice Major Garey
was on duty with a committee of
general headquarters, A. E. F., engaged in compiling special war
records. He is co-author, with
Major Ellis and Prof. R. V. D.
Magoffin, of "The American Guide

Book to France and Its Battlefields." Last year Major Garey
assisted Colonel Ellis in the management of the unit's spring field
work during the trying period of
inspection for "distinguished"
classification.
Major Garey married Miss Alice
B. Ross, daughter of Admiral Ross
of the United States Navy, and is
now living in Roland Park.

Beverly Smith '19 and Graham Heiner
'21 Win Coveted Honor. Two Hopkins Men Already in England.

This fall two more Hopkins men
have received the Rhodes Scholarship. Beverly Waugh Smith, '19,
and Robert Graham Heiner, '21,
are the two students thus honored.
Smith graduated from Hopkins in
1919, having completed his undergraduate course in three years.
Since graduating he has studied
at the Harvard Law School at
Johns Hopkins. "Bev" was captain
of the track team in his Senior
year and holder of J. H. U. indoor
and outdoor records for the quarter mile. He was a member of the
Athletic Board and Debating
Council, and of Alpha Delta Phi,
Omicron Delta Kappa and Phi
Beta Kappa societies.
Smith is appointed for 1920
from the State of Maryland, and
will leave for Oxford in January,
1921, to complete his course in
law.
R. Graham Heiner was awarded
his scholarship by a unanimous
decision of the Georgia Committee. He is a member of the
Class of 1921, and leaves for England next October, where he also
intends to study law. At Hopkins,
Heiner is this year's editor of the
Hullaballoo, president of the
Omicron Delta Kappa, president
of the Debating Council, and a
participant in other college activities.

Oxford the number of Hopkins
Rhodes scholars there will be increased to four. Alexander K.
Barton, J. H. U.,. '14, began his
Oxford studies last autumn, and
Frank V. Morley, J. H. U.,'18, left
this September for England. Former Rhodes scholars from Johns

Y. M. C. A. HOLDS ANNUAL
RECEPTION
Dr. French Addresses Students in Behalf of Faculty—Student Organizations Poorly Represented.
The Y. M. C. A. reception to the
Freshmen, held Friday evening in
the Civil Engineering Hall, attracted an almost 100 per cent.
attendance of Freshmen • but the
affair lacked the cordiality it
would have possessed had more
upper classmen been present. The
Y. M. C. A., Harold Reed and Mr.
E. Pearce Hayes deserve a great
measure of credit for the success
the reception, nevertheless, proved
to be.
Harold Reed opened the evening
by introducing Dr. French, who
made the-welcoming speech of the
faculty to the Freshmen. Dr.
French's remarks took the form of
a few words • of advice which he
said he had to offer, and although
given to Freshmen, the advice is
good for every Hopkins man.
Following Dr. French's address
the assembly heard a few words
from Coach Van Orman, Mr. Kistler and Assistant Coach Wilcox.
The officers of the various activities then presented their organizations' aims to the Freshmen.
The number of these executives
absent was deplorable and against
every Hopkins tradition. During
these announcements the whole
Sophomore class filed out in anticipation of the traditional rush
of
which was to follow the serving
•
refreshments.
The rush proved to be a mildly
interesting event, in which the
honors must go to the Sophomores, although the Freshmen
soon became kings of the walk
when they had found a leader to
take the place of their president,
Hubert Barton, who was pre•vented from participating by the
necessity of keeping in trim for
the morrow's football game. The
Sophomores, however, had by this
time kidnapped a score or more of
Freshmen and transported them
to unknown rural parts. The recent split, reported at their last
class meeting, does not seem to
have affected their well-known
ability to organize for a fight
ahead of time.
The Impossible and the Difficult.

The only difference is that it
takes longer to do the impossible.
The impossible was accomplished
lasit week when the Y. M. C. A.
.was able to secure sufficient rooming and boarding places for all the
students. Homes were found for
250 men and women. It is a safe
prediction to make that unless the
dormitories are ready for use next
year, many students will be compelled to live at a distance from
the University.

Downs Mt. St. Mary's by 33 to 14 Score. Fumbles Costly for

The Johns Hopkins football team ushered in its 1920 season by
coming from behind and defeating the eleven of Mt. St. Mary's College
by the score of 33 to 14. After the first quarter no one could doubt
that Hopkins was the superior, both on the offensive and the defensive,
for Mt. St. Mary's was unable to stop their powerful smashes through
the line, while her own attack, except at rare intervals, was smothered
by the Black and Blue. The Mountaineers were greatly aided during
the first quarter by several costly fumbles committed by Hopkins, but
their early advantage, and with it the gloom of the Homewood stands,
soon passed when Van Orman's squad found itself and swung into its
real stride.
The contest was characterized by both teams' use of straight football, the great majority of the plays being made through the center of
the line or off-tackle. Hopkins did not attempt a single forward pass,
while Mt. St. Mary's two attempts were failures; one was grounded
and the other.intercepted.. Neither side gained much by the numerous
punts made during the first half, though St. Mary's seemed to get
down under the ball faster. The game was a straight contest in line
•
plunging, and the more powerful and better trained team won.
Elmer Jones stood head and shoulders above any man on the field,
although it would be hard to pick a really weak spot in the Hopkins
machine. He plowed through the line with all his old power, and on
the defensive backed up the line with a rush that instilled respect into
the biggest upstater on the field. Right behind him were Calkins and
Skinner with their dashing smashes, and Landy and McKay, who
always opened up a big hole when it was most needed. For Mt. St.
Mary's, Captain Chapman was the whole show. He scored all of his
team's points, and was, in fact, the only man who could make any
impression at all on the Hopkins defense. He seemed to be right in
the thick of every play, and supplied the only punch that the Mountaineers possessed.

AMBITIOUS PROGRAM
PLANNED
Production Equal to the "Admiral
Crichton," and Several Smaller
Plays Will Probably Be Presented by Dramatic Club.

Production by the Dramatic
Club of a play equal in size to the
"Admirable Crichton" which the
club produced last year is on the
schedule of the dramatic organization for the coining year, according_ to an announcement made last
week by officials of the club. In
addition, several smaller plays,
such as were presented in the
"Barn" last year, will be offered if
there is sufficient demand for
them. The principal play to be
produced has not yet been decided
upon, but it is regarded as certain
that a production of lavish size
and demanding considerable histronic talent will be offered.
Opportunities for members of
the lower classes to-get a place in
the productions of the club are excellent. The club finds itself in
the singular position of having but
eight members of the cast and
business staff remaining, all the
others having graduated last
spring. Consequently, there will
be an excellent opportunity for
ambitious men who wish to show
their school spirit to become members of the club and take part in
the productions. Notice for tryouts in the cast will be made as
soon as the play is definitely decided upon.
It is hoped that Miss Clementine Walter, under whose able direction the plays during the last
three years have been produced,
can be prevailed upon to coach for
one more year. Her assistance in
past-years has been immensely valuable to the Dramatic Club, and
the club would feel completely lost
without her help. Bartus Trew,
president of the club, has not returned from his trip west, and in
the meantime Holmes Boyd is in
complete charge.
The only thing that will limit
the activities of the club will be
the state of finances, according to
Holmes Boyd, the business manager. At present the financial affairs of the club are at a rather
low ebb and will not permit a very
pretentious schedule, but it is certain that after a thorough reorganization the club will be able to
furnish at least as much to the
dramatic activities of the University as last year.

At the first Assembly of the
student body last Thursday, Dean
Latane explained the purpose of
these scheduled weekly gatherings.
The first few meetings will be confined to various announcements,
but later the hour will be devoted
to addresses by prominent outside
men. Dr. Latane requested the
students' co-operation in, making
this a feature of college life at
Hopkins.
• He then explained that the student body here had been placed
on a. basis of self-government
through the student council and
the acceptance of the honor system. The honor system, he asserted, must be rigidly enforced,
'because the University cannot afford to put its stamp on it man
when he goes out from its halls
unless he has a high sense of
honor.
Coach Van Orman made -a brief
address, in which he asserted that
with the loyal support of the student body, in spite of the heavy
schedule, the team may be expected to win a majority of its
games.
Mr. Kistler requested all students to assist him in collecting a
mailing list and selling season
tickets. Ninety-five jobs have
been created in connection with
the football season, which he announced would be given to deserving men.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 5, 1920

With the inauguration of the
year 1920-1921, the News-Letter
looks forward with a great deal
of confidence and hope to the making of a banner year at Johns
Hopkins, not only in scholastic attainments, but in athletic prowess
and all other branches of endeavor.
Our facilities for learning are
improving as each year goes by.
We are becoming acclimated to
our new surroundings at Homewood; more and better equipment
is being placed at the disposal of
the students, and the dormitories,
which, we hope, will put the last
touch on the "get-together" spirit,
will soon be built. With their
completion the "big family" at
Homewood wil feel itself to be
truly a crowd of brothers, pulling
ever more and more for each tither
and for the Alma Mater, and the
college spirit manifested at other
colleges will, we have every con- fidence in assuming, find adequate
soil for growth at Homewood.
But why wait for the dormitories? Let us prove that we can
have that spirit without them.
Our athletic outlook far surpasses that of any year previous,
both in the schedules and quality
of play which will be exhibited.
We face this year the most difficult schedules yet compiled in every branch of sport; our coaching
system outshines that of previous
years, and the material with which
the coaches have to work is better than in years past.

The only way for Johns Hopkins to uphold her end of the arduous schedules assumed this year is
for every man in the University to
put forth his best. Go out for the
teams. If you are not physically
qualified to • make a team, attend
the games, cheer your comrades to
success by your presence and your
voice. Show Baltimoreans that
you are back of your teams heart
and soul, ready to support them
in defeat as well as in victory.
Nothing does a team, fighting an
uphill battle, more good than to
know that every colleze-mate is in
the stands, watching its every play
and pulling for it to deliver the
goods.
Welcome to the University,
Freshmen! We are truly glad to
accept you into our midst.
As you have all undoubtedly observed, there are a few light regulations which you are called upon
to obey. Do not get the idea that
this is hazing; that these small
hardships are placed on your
shoulders by the Sophomores to
afford them amusement at your
expense.
These regulations are put in
force by the Student Council for
your own welfare—to teach you
your position in the University, to
make true and loyal Hopkins men
out of you. The Sophomores are
automatically appointed to carry
out these regulations, but bear in
mind that the entire student body,
and likewise the faculty, is behind
them, ready, if necessary, to aid
the Class of '23 in executing them
to the letter.
Let us hope that you will obey
these regulations with a good
grace, accepting them at their face
value, and bearing no malice
against their enforcers.
If you do this, rest assured that
you will be accepted sooner—and
with greater pleasure—as faithful
college-mates.
As you may have read elsewhere in this issue, the Johns Hopkins R. 0. T. C. has sent out a plea
for recruits. The Johns Hopkins
Unit has ever stood among the
leaders in this branch of the service, in spite of the many hardships
which it has been called upon to
face, and the University is justly
proud of its achievement's.
That the Unit may continue to
hold its place among the leaders,
it requires the support of the
student-body. It needs men -men ready to work with its interests at heart who are not afraid of
a little trouble and exertion.
Show Major Gary, whose face
has been seen in our midst but a
short while, that you are with him
in his plans to put Hopkins at the
head of the R. 0. T. C. Units
throughout the country show him
that we have red-blooded Americans at college who are willing
to support a good thing, and enroll
in the Johns Hopkins Unit. It
will be a step which you will have
no cause to reget later, and will
afford you splendid training for
after-life, as well as giving' you
several credits toward graduation.

The NEWS-LETTER is facing this
year an increase in its printing
cost of over thirty per cent. By
increasing its advertising rates
and raising its subscription it has
been able to meet a large proportion of this increase, but in order
to have a safe margin it needs a
one hundred per cent. student subscription list. Pay your NEWSLETTER bill now at the postoffice
or at the NEWS-LETTER office, and
thus show that the NEWS-LETTER
has your support.
Within the next few days the
Junior and Senior classes will
elect their officers for the coming
year. The real value of these class
offices depends upon the ability
and character of the men Who fill
them. It is therefore of the utmost importance that these Masses
select suitable men for these positions. They should select men
who during their stay at college
have proved themselves popular,
efficient, capable and, above all,
imbued with college spirit and a
willingness to sacrifice themselves
personally for the good of the University. The prestige of these
classes and the good of the University will be seriously affected if
the men are chosen solely on the
grounds of athletic prominence or
false popularity.
WHEN THE CLASS IS OVER, and
you have nothing else to do,
come down to the "Barn" and play
the piano, read the magazines and
daily newspapers, or just loaf.
This room is furnished by the Y.
M. C. A., and is for your use at
any and all times.

Lost-and-Found Bureau.

A long-felt need has been met in
the establishment of the University Lost and Found Bureau. The
conduct of the bureau will be in
the hands of the University Y. M.
C. A., with John P. Stump,'23,'in
charge.
Articles lost or found are to be
reported to the bureau in the Y. M.
C. A. office, where a receipt will be
(riven to the finder. Articles unclaimed after a period of two
weeks will be returned to the
finder. The bureau will post a
daily report on the bulletin-board
near the postoffice.

R.0. T. C. CALLS FOR RECRUITS.

The Editor of the NEWS-LETTER
has kindly invited me to write an
article explaining the plans for
the coming, year in the Military
Department. In availing myself
of this offer I desire, first, to pay
tribute to my predecessors, Majors
Guild and Ellis, for their services
in this department to the institution. It will be a source of no little satisfaction to the University
to learn that not only their general policy, but many of the details of their administration, have
been accepted by the War Department as a model, and instructions
have just been issued inaugurating the Johns Hopkins system of
military training in all the colleges and universities of the entire
country having infantry training.
The new instructions vitally
change all previous R. 0. T. C.
methods at all institutions except
this one. In this work I was taken
into the confidence of the War Department and have assisted somewhat in the preparation of the
new scheme of instruction for the
country.
To have a Military Department
in the distinguished class three
years after the department was
started is, I believe, a unique record. Major Guild designed the
structure and built the foundation. Major Ellis finished the
work. It will be my policy to continue their policy.
The following interesting and
far-reaching method of appointments in the unit goes into effect
at once: Every second-year man
will be a non-commissioned officer. Those who have been most
proficient and valuable will be sergeant-major or first sergeants
others on down to the grade of
lance corporals. Every man in the
third-year course will be a first
lieutenant, a second lieutenant or
an additional second lieutenant.
Every fourth-year student will be
a field officer, a captain or an additional captain.
The purpose of the above arrangement is to put upper classmen in the position of leaders.
They are to be given opportunities
to command, thus developing by
actual practice the qualities of
Leadership not only indispensible
in military activities, but also valuable in most of civic pursuits.
The Military Department is not
wholly attempting to make soldiers out of the men taking its
training. Not one man in a hundred in this University will go in
the army. With all other Amen--

cans I hope and pray that we may
never again be called upon to go
to war. But such an ideal cannot
be expected. Assuredly in hoping
with all our hearts for peace, no
real American would have us fail
to be reasonably prepared for
whatever eventualities may arise.
The men who served in the
World war have done their full
and honorable duty. They should
now step off the stage. The new
generation should take their
places and assume their work.
The R. 0. T. C. is a means for the.
young men to do so.
Johns Hopkins has taken the
initiative in the new War Department's system of training. Its
schedule for the year is being blueprinted and sent to every college
in the country that has infantry
training. Also, the Johns Hopkins lesson sheets for the year are
being sent all over the country.
That means that we must not
only remain on the distinguished
list, but that we are making a positive and energetic drive ,to stand
No. 1 and to be so recognized
throughout the country.
I can assure every man that
the Johns Hopkins unit has the
respect and confidence of the War
Oepartment. I have been advised
that several important heads of
departments and committees are
coming over this next year to inspect the unit and to see at first
hand the course of instruction
that is having far-reaching results
throughout the country. To be
worthy of our task this new department in the University needs
the moral support and active assistance of every man in it. The
question is this: Shall we continue to have it grow and develop,
or shall we rest on laurels previously won? To come up to the
highest expectations of the Universi[ty authorities and the War
Department we need two things—
first, good men second, hard
work.
To be perfectly frank, we want
no slackers. Only men who want
to put their shoulders to the wheel
and 'push hard are desired. The
Government is offering many attractive features to R. 0. T. C.
men.. The University grants them
liberal credits for graduation. I
have an adequate staff of most
able: assistants. We are going to
give the R. 0, T. C. men our levelbest work. We expect the R. 0.
T. C. men in the unit to give us
50-50.
The first year is devoted to foot
work. The following three years

The Hopkins football team this
year has the honor and responsibility of being the first team to
represent Hopkins on the field under the new athletic regime. It
is the first team to be backed adequately in a financial way, and is
unusually fortunate in being sufficiently equipped, fed at a training table and in having the services of so excellent a coach as Dr.
Van Orman. But these advantages, so customary for other big
colleges and so unique at Hopkins, are not nearly so unprecedented as the training trip to
Camp Red Cloud which the team
took during two weeks in September.
The main body of the squad arrived in camp Monday morning,
September 6, and from that moment till they toiled to break
camp on Saturday, the 18th, the
aspiring gridders lived a hard,
regular life, 15 miles from the
nearest jazz emporium, and that
same 15 miles from -"sugar and
spice and everything nice." But
the hardening procesii was not
left entirely to the routinte of
camp life; the main object of all
this hardening was not allowed to
leave the men's minds for a moment, and Coach Van Orman put
them through two driving football
practices daily. Any spare time
was put in with the axe at the
woodpile or in the woods, swimming in Silver Lake or canoeing
thereon, or in that grand old indoor sport of listening to chalk
talks.
All the time at camp was not
taken up with work, however, and
all the camp life was not hardship, for Camp Red Cloud is a
really ideal camp. Situated on
the shore of Silver Lake, fairly in
the midst of the beautiful trees
that fringe its icy waters, the
camp offered opportunities for
rare fishing and swimming. Since
the lake is over 1800 feet above
sea level, it is entirely spring-fed,
and its waters are so clear that
one can see bottom when the waters are 15 feet deep.
The team this year is a good
one, but, facing such an unusually
heavy schedule, it could scarcely
have attempted to start the season without these preparations.
The schedule, which follows, contains four big games and no easy
ones:
October 2 — Mount St. Mary's,
at Homewood.
. October 9—Syracuse, at Syracuse.
October 16—University of Virginia, at Homewood.
October 23 — Swarthmore, at
Homewood.
October 30 — Georgetown, at
Homewood.
November 6 — Haverford, at
Haverford.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 5, 1920
DEPARTMENT OF PSYCHOLOGY
PRESENTS NEW COURSE.
The department of psychology
has announced for the present
year the inauguration of a new
course in the psychology of music,
to be conducted by Mr. Otto Ortmann, who has recently been appointed an instructor in the University. Mr. Ortman has been for
the past eight years a teacher of
piano at the Peabody Conservatory of Music, and for some time
instructor in music at the Park
School, and has, moreover, done
quite an amount of composing.
The course which he is to give
represents one of the most modern
and recent branches of experimental psychology, and is one of
the first to be attempted in this
particular department of the science. Its fundamental problem
will be the investigation of the
underlying causes of human reactions to certain types of• sounds
and of compositions, the reasons
for the difference in the impressions conveyed, and the effect of
various outside factors on our general'response.
Such a study will lead to a comparison of the different systems of
music, many of which have been
developed by a particular nation.
Experiment will also be made
with tone systems other than the
one now in universal use throughout Europe and America, which
divides the scale into twelve halftones. The chief purpose of the
instruction will thus be to show
the intimate relation which exists
between science and music, and
the dependence of the latter on the
former.
The new course will also deal
with the practical phase of the
study of music, taking up the various forms of music, types of composition, the historical development of harmony,and the study of
rhythm.
Although the course is intended
primarily for graduate students,
those who can show sufficient mu
sical training will be admitted, in
spite of their lack of bachelor's degree. Moreover, a large amount of
technical training is not required,
for one need not be able to play a
particular instrument to gain ad
mission.
November 13—St. John's College, at Homewood.
November 20 — Western Maryland College, at Homewood.
November 25 — University of
Maryland (Maryland State), at
Homewood.

MAJOR CAREY TO HEAD
UNIT
Will Take Place of Captain Ellis who
Retired. Unit to March in
Inaugural Parade.

The organization of the Johns
Hopkins unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps will take
place Tuesday, October 5, at 4
P. M. The battalion this year is
under the command of Maj. Enoch
B. Garey, who succeeds Captain
Ellis as Professor of Military Science and Tactics. The adjutant of
the military department is Capt.
T. L. McMurray, Infantry, and
Major Garey is also assisted by
Regt. Sergt.-Major E. Grummon.
•Members of the unit will wear
on their uniforms this year a gold
star to signify that their outfit is
on the "Distinguished List" of 15
colleges. Uniforms will be issued
during this week.
Enrollment in the unit this fall
promises to be a record one, and it
was stimulated last week by the
appearance of a notice to this
effect:
"Arrangements are now being
made for this unit to march in the
inaugural parade in Washington
on March 4,. 1921, and unless unforeseen circumstances arise it
may be assumed that the battalion
will participate in the parade.
"(Signed) E. B. GAREY,
"Major, Infantry."
Maj. Enoch B. Garey, our new
Professor of Military Science and
Tactics, is a native of Denton,Md.,
and is the son of the late Col. R. J.
W. Garey and Mrs. Garey. He is
a graduate of St. John's and West
Point. As a lieutenant-colonel
in the American Expeditionary
Forces, Major Garey saw active
service in France during the late
summer of 1918. On September
17 of that year Major Garey, in
command of the Eighteenth Machine Gun Battalion of the Sixth
Division, led a daring attack
against the Germans in the Vosges
Mountains for which he was
awarded the Croix de Guerre.
After the armistice Major Garey
was on duty with a committee of
general headquarters, A. E. F., engaged in compiling special war
records. He is co-author, with
Major Ellis and Prof. R. V. D.
Magoffin, of "The American Guide

Book to France and Its Battlefields." Last year Major Garey
assisted Colonel Ellis in the management of the unit's spring field
work during the trying period of
inspection for "distinguished"
classification.
Major Garey married Miss Alice
B. Ross, daughter of Admiral Ross
of the United States Navy, and is
now living in Roland Park.

RHODES SCHOLARSHIPS
FOR TWO

BALTIMORE, MD

Beverly Smith '19 and Graham Heiner
'21 Win Coveted Honor. Two Hopkins Men Already in England.

This fall two more Hopkins men
have received the Rhodes Scholarship. Beverly Waugh Smith, '19,
and Robert Graham Heiner, '21,
are the two students thus honored.
Smith graduated from Hopkins in
1919, having completed his undergraduate course in three years.
Since graduating he has studied
at the Harvard Law School at
Johns Hopkins. "Bev" was captain
of the track team in his Senior
year and holder of J. H. U. indoor
and outdoor records for the quarter mile. He was a member of the
Athletic Board and Debating
Council, and of Alpha Delta Phi,
Omicron Delta Kappa and Phi
Beta Kappa societies.
Smith is appointed for 1920
from the State of Maryland, and
will leave for Oxford in January,
1921, to complete his course in
law.
R. Graham Heiner was awarded
his scholarship by a unanimous
decision of the Georgia Committee. He is a member of the
Class of 1921, and leaves for England next October, where he also
intends to study law. At Hopkins,
Heiner is this year's editor of the
Hullaballoo, president of the
Omicron Delta Kappa, president
of the Debating Council, and a
participant in other college activities.
With the arrival of these men at
Oxford the number of Hopkins
Rhodes scholars there will be increased to four. Alexander K.
Barton, J. H. U.,. '14, began his
Oxford studies last autumn, and
Frank V. Morley, J. H. U.,'18, left
this September for England. Former Rhodes scholars from Johns

Y. M. C. A. CAMPAIGN

FOOTBALL

Every-Member Canvass of Undergraduate Body Planned—Student
Support Needed.

Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of this week have been set
aside as the time for the financial
campaign of the Hopkins Y. M.
C. A. Each year the opportunity
is given Hopkins students to express their appreciation of the
work of the association by con•
tributing to the successful continuance of this branch of student
life.
The plan to be followed this year
is an every-member canvass of the
;undergraduate body, under the
personal supervision of the general secretary, E. Pearce Hayes.
Subscriptions will be solicited by
teams, but anyone may make his
.contribution by applying in person at the office in the "Barn."
As the association grows
through increased usefulness into
a leading feature of student activities, there is a corresponding en• largement of the year's budget;
consequently, there is no hesitation in urging a proportionately
heartier response from the student
body.
